section.title: Referring to elements and attributes
section.p: When referring to elements use angle brackets around the element and add the word “element”. For example: “This table is built using a <simpletable> element.” When refering to elements in plural, always use the singular element in angle brackets, followed by the plural “elements”. For example, “Each row can contain one or more <stentry> elements.”
When referring to attributes, use the word “attribute”. Do not use an at-sign (@) before an attribute name; this is an XPath convention and means nothing to those learning DITA.

section.title: Quotes and apostrophe
section.p: Use the proper apostrophe (’, U+2019) and quotation marks (“ and ”, U+201C and U+201D) in your text. In code examples, use straight quotes. From the Macintosh keyboard, you can enter apostrophe with Option+Shift+], an opening double quote with Option+[, and a closing double quote with Option+Shift+[.

For Windows, either memorize the Alt- keystroke sequence, or create an Oxygen code template (or the equivalent in your preferred XML editor), which you can associate with a keystroke. Alternately, you can do a search and replace to clean up the quotes and apostrophes, but be careful with any code examples.

section.title: Code examples
section.p: Because of restrictions in the DITA 1.2 learningContent model, a <task> element can only contain elements allowed by the learningContent topic type. Thus, any code examples must use the <pre> element, and not the <codeblock> element.

section.title: DITA Editors
section.p: When talking about a DITA-aware editor, just use the term “DITA editor”. No need for “DITA-aware” or “DITA-savvy”.
When talking about Oxygen, use “oXygen XML Editor”.
